channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis Unswayed by Houthi Rebels’ Overture in Yemen
item.description: Rebel leaders announced on Saturday that they had appointed four key ministers from the Yemeni government they had overthrown, but Saudi Arabia and its allies denounced the plan.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Australia’s Leader Expedites Vote Threatening His Job
item.description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia moved forward a vote that would declare his position vacant in an effort to reduce uncertainty before Parliament returns from summer recess.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: World Briefing: Taiwan: Pilots Begin Tests
item.description: The dozens of pilots who operate the ATR propeller-jets of TransAsia Airways began proficiency tests on Saturday, three days after one of the carrier’s planes crashed into a river.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Kenya: Lawmaker Is Killed
item.description: A masked gunman shot and killed a Kenyan lawmaker and three other people early Saturday on a street in the capital, Nairobi, a senior police official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Bombings Extend Political Violence
item.description: Assailants threw fire bombs at a packed bus and a truck in two separate attacks in Bangladesh, killing at least nine people and wounding 30 others, the police said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nigeria Postpones Elections, Saying Security Is a Concern
item.description: The closely contested presidential election, originally scheduled for next Saturday, will be held March 28, an official said. But any delay has been opposed by a rival candidate and the Obama administration.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention
item.description: The High Court in Baluchistan has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the houbara bustard in response to complaints from conservationists.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistanis last year in Baluchistan Province with their catch of houbara bustard. Foreign hunting permits have been canceled.

item.title: Curfew’s End Brings Hope and Fear to Baghdad
item.description: Hours before the government planned to lift a nighttime curfew, explosions ripped through three neighborhoods in the capital.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Three blasts tore through Baghdad on Saturday, killing at least 36 people. Municipal workers helped clean a street filled with hardware stores that was hit.

item.title: ISIS Declares Airstrike Killed a U.S. Hostage
item.description: The Islamic State said Friday that Jordanian bombings in Syria intended to avenge the immolation of a captured pilot had killed an American hostage, Kayla Mueller, who was held by the group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Matt Hinshaw/The Daily Courier, via Associated Press

item.title: Mayor of Paris Grows Into Her New Role as Comforter in Chief
item.description: Mayor Anne Hidalgo, a soft-spoken but ambitious politician pushed into the spotlight by a terrorist attack, has developed a new swagger.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Mayor Anne Hidalgo survived the 2014 municipal elections, during which the left was trounced.

item.title: In Gaza and the West Bank, Love Struggles to Bridge the Separation
item.description: An inability to travel freely between Gaza and the West Bank affects thousands of Palestinians, human rights groups say. Since Hamas came to power in Gaza, exit into Israel has been allowed only for humanitarian cases.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dalia Shurrab, with her wedding gown, at her home in Khan Younis in southern Gaza. Her fiancé, Rashed Sameer Faddah, lives in the West Bank city of Nablus. Their inability to travel freely between the territories has delayed their marriage plans.

item.title: Memo From Argentina: Whodunit? In Obsessed Nation, Question Becomes Who Didn’t
item.description: Argentina has been awash in theories about who killed Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish community center.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina and Alberto Nisman in May 2013. Mr. Nisman had accused Mrs. Kirchner of conspiring to cover up responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires, claims she has rejected.

item.title: Shiite Militia Drives Back Islamic State, but Divides Much of Iraq
item.description: The Badr Organization, a Shiite militia, has been effective in fighting the Islamic State, but stands among the most divisive in Iraq, accused of atrocities against Sunnis and known for its close ties to Iran.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Shiite militia fighters of the Badr Organization celebrating in Diyala Province after defeating Islamic State militants. The militias are feared by Sunnis who accuse them of summary killings.

item.title: News Analysis: Surviving the Nazis, Only to Be Jailed by America
item.description: “Displaced persons” were still behind barbed wire and under armed guard.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:credit: Margaret Bourke-White/Time & Life Pictures — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prisoners at the Buchenwald concentration camp, near Weimar, Germany, as it was liberated by American forces in April 1945.

item.title: Top Aide Leaps to Defense of Obama Security Stance
item.description: As President Obama officially rolled out a new national security strategy, Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, denounced “alarmism” over various international crises.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser, at the Brookings Institution in Washington on Friday, where she called for “a sense of perspective” in assessing foreign policy threats.

item.title: China Purges a Party’s Rolls (and Tissues)
item.description: The authorities in southern China have seized about 8,000 rolls of toilet paper containing unflattering images of Hong Kong’s chief executive, according to an official of the small political party that placed the order.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Luxury Condos Unlocked
item.description: The New York Times investigates the millionaire and billionaire luxury condominium buyers who use real estate as a safe deposit box for their money.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Stream of Foreign Wealth Flows to Elite New York Real Estate
item.description: Shell companies are used to shield the identities of buyers in the competition to secure condos at the Time Warner Center and other high-end buildings. This is the first installment in a five-part series.
item.dc:creator: By LOUISE STORY and STEPHANIE SAUL
item.media:description: Construction of the Time Warner Center, whose two lighted towers are at center, ignited the development of a billionaires row of residential towers overlooking Central Park.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Summary: The Hidden Money Buying Up New York Real Estate
item.description: An influx of global cash, much of it anonymously held, is helping to drive the growth in luxury real estate sales, a New York Times investigation has found.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Western Nations Split on Arming Kiev Forces
item.description: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, said she opposed providing lethal military support to Kiev during a security conference in Munich on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ALISON SMALE and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Angela Merkel and Petro O. Poroshenko in Munich.
